Agudeza Ontology

Ontology Design

Formalising the critical debate surrounding the Agudeza into a universal discourse

Requirements: General


The requirements of any ontology may come from:

  • Research into the domain of interest in order to understand its tendencies and rules
  • Domain experts, who can provide useful information on concepts and relationships within the domain of interest
  • The main purpose of the ontology, i.e. the tasks you want the ontology to perform when you use it to encode data (e.g. for inferences, or simply for curation and preservation)

Ontologies designed using these means are designed using a top-down approach. The Agudeza Ontology is a top-down ontology in this respect. It has been designed:

  • After research into the domain of interest in the form of collecting and processing data on 3 critics’ analyses
  • In dialogue with a domain expert (myself), who is knowledgeable about the domain and can provide useful pointers on its key ideas and tendencies, supplementing and contextualising the information extracted from the data analysis
  • With the primary purpose of describing and preserving data, but open to the possibility of interesting and insightful inferences emerging (this is hard to anticipate prior to the creation of the ontology)

Requirements: Agudeza Ontology


Based upon a combination of data analysis and domain expertise, the universal discourse of the domain – representing the critical universe of the Agudeza – to be incorporated within the Agudeza Ontology has been abstracted into the following summary. Bold type represents a class and underlined type represents a sub-class.

The ‘Agudeza y arte de ingenio’ by Baltasar Gracián has been subject to dissenting analyses by critics. These dissenting analyses stem primarily from dissenting understandings of Gracián’s key terms and the extent to which each key term contributes and relates to the process of connection making. Some key terms have to do with man’s intellectual faculties; other key terms have to do with ontological realms; other key terms have to do with central concepts. Some critics consider all key terms; some critics consider only a few. The way in which key terms link to each other varies by critic. Depending upon the nature of these links, the philosophical scope via which each critic analyses Gracián’s ‘Agudeza’ can be deduced. Critics use different symbolic imagery when analysing the ‘Agudeza’ and this symbolic imagery tends to relate to certain key terms and philosophical scopes. Some critics refer to the work of other critics, others do not. Some critics refer to other works by Gracián in their analyses, others do not.

Concretisations of this universal discourse for the 3 critics already analysed would be the following:

Sarmiento

Sarmiento considers the following key terms: ‘agudeza’, ‘wit’, ‘concepto’, ‘ingenio’, ‘conceit’, and ‘reason’. For Sarmiento, ‘agudeza’ is equivalent to ‘wit’; ‘agudeza’ is equivalent to the ‘conceit’; ‘agudeza’ results from the ‘concepto’; ‘agudeza’ belongs to the realm of ‘parecer’; and the ‘concepto’ belongs to the realm of ‘ser’. For Sarmiento, both ‘reason’ and ‘intuition’ contribute to connection making. The philosophical scope of Sarmiento’s analysis lies within the remits of Rhetoric and Aesthetics. Sarmiento uses symbolic imagery of fire – representing ‘agudeza’ – and light – representing ‘ser’ and the ‘concepto’ – in his analysis. He does not refer to other critics’ work. And he does not refer to other works by Gracián.

Parker

Parker considers the following key terms: ‘agudeza’, ‘concepto’, ‘ingenio’, ‘wit’, ‘conceptus’, ‘conceit’, ‘reason’. For Parker, ‘agudeza’ is equivalent to ‘wit’; ‘agudeza’ is equivalent to the ‘conceit’; ‘agudeza’ results from the ‘concepto’; ‘agudeza’ belongs to the realm of ‘parecer’; ‘agudeza’ and the ‘concepto’ cannot be combined into the ‘conceptus’; and ‘ingenio’ is different to ‘reason’. For Parker, ‘reason’ contributes to connection making. Due to this, the philosophical scope of Parker’s analysis lies within the remit of Rhetoric. Parker uses symbolic imagery of lips, roses, and lions – all representing the realm of ‘parecer’ – in his analysis. He refers to Sarmiento within his analysis. And he does not refer to other works by Gracián.

Beattie

Beattie considers the following key terms: ‘agudeza’, ‘concepto’, ‘ingenio’, ‘conceptus’, ‘conceit’, ‘juicio’, ‘prudence’, ‘reason’, ‘gusto’, ‘ser’, ‘parecer’. For Beattie, ‘juicio’ is equivalent to ‘reason’; ‘agudeza’ and the ‘concepto’ are inter-dependent; ‘agudeza’ and the ‘concepto’ combine into the ‘conceptus’; ‘ingenio’ is equivalent to ‘intuition’; ‘gusto’ is equivalent to ‘intuition’; ‘reason’ can be trained into ‘ingenio’ using ‘prudence’; and ‘ingenio’ perceives the ‘conceptus’. For Beattie, ‘reason’, ‘intuition’, and ‘ingenio’ contribute to connection making. Due to this, the philosophical scope of Beattie’s analysis lies within the remits of Ontology, Aesthetics, Epistemology, and Ethics. Beattie uses symbolic imagery of the sun – representing ‘ser’ and Epistemology –, the starry sky – representing ‘ingenio’, ‘agudeza’ and the ‘concepto’ –, and the cave – representing ‘parecer’ and Epistemology. She refers to criticism by Sarmiento, Parker, Woods, Blanco, and Andersen. And she refers to Gracián’s ‘El Héroe’, ‘El Discreto’, ‘El Criticón’, and ‘El Comulgatorio’ in her analysis.

Informal Competency Questions


Given this abstraction of the universal discourse of the Agudeza Ontology, the following competency questions summaries the knowledge we can hope to extract from a knowledge graph created using this ontology:

CQ1: Which key terms does each critic consider?
CQ2: How do the key terms considered by each critic link with each other?
CQ3: How do key terms used by the critic contribute to connection making?
CQ4: What is the philosophical scope of each critic’s analysis?
CQ5: What symbolic imagery is used by each critic?
CQ6: What does the symbolic imagery used by each critic represent?
CQ7: To which other critics does each critic refer?
CQ8: To which other works by Gracián does each critic refer?

Hierarchy of Classes (With Named Individuals)


The following represents the hierarchy of classes which will make up the Agudeza Ontology, populated with individuals extracted from the 3 original critical analyses. Individuals were added to the Analysis and Critic classes in order to facilitate references to all prominent critics who have worked on Gracián’s Agudeza, not limiting the applicability of the ontology to only the 3 initial critics.

Object and Data Properties (With Domains and Ranges)

One particularity of the Agudeza Ontology is that the links between the individuals of the class KeyTerm are highly significant and are often more revealing than the classes of the ontology themselves. Therefore, these property links need to be curated carefully, taking into account the specific subclasses of KeyTerm that they can be used connect.

Other properties:

Agudeza Ontology: RDF Format

The classes, properties, and named individuals of the Agudeza Ontology were inputted into Protégé in order to create the universal domain of the Agudeza Ontology. The software’s reasoner was run in order to ascertain if there were any inferences to be made. Inferences included: that the object property interdependentOn is the inverse property of itself, as is the object property equivalentTo. Furthermore, annotations were added to the ontology – using predicates such as rdfs:comment, rdfs:domain, rdfs:range, rdfs:subClassOf, owl:sameAs, owl:inverseOf, owl:disjointWith – in order to document how the ontology should be used for a human user.

The global Agudeza Ontology was exported from Protégé in RDF format, serialised in Turtle syntax, and validated by the IDLab Turtle validator. The ttl file can be accessed here.

Agudeza Ontology: Visualisation

The universal domain of the Agudeza Ontology was then visualised using the RDF Grapher Tool.
